steps: Get Computer Science or related degree
Apply to junior positions in final year
Choose reputable bootcamp (check job placement rates)
Build real projects, not just tutorials
Contribute to open source on GitHub
Identify transferable skills from current role
Learn programming focused on your domain (e.g., finance ΓåÆ fintech)
Build projects related to previous expertise
Network with developers in your industry
Apply for junior/mid roles that value domain knowledge

careerPath.description: Focus on mathematics, physics, and computer science. Join coding clubs.
Earn Bachelor's in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or IT.
requirements: Strong performance in Math and Physics

fullDescription: Software developers design, build, test, and maintain applications and systems. You'll write code, debug issues, collaborate with teams, and continuously learn new technologies. The reality is less 'coding genius' and more 'professional problem solver who Googles a lot.'

bestFor: Love solving puzzles and logical problems
Comfortable with ambiguity and constant change
Can sit and focus for long periods
cons: Imposter syndrome is constant - always someone better
Tech changes fast - need continuous learning or fall behind
Initial job hunt is brutal (100+ applications common)
notFor: Need immediate tangible results (takes time to see impact)
Need clear success metrics (coding is often subjective)
pros: High salary potential - 36M RWF to 120M+ RWF in Rwanda
Remote work flexibility - work from anywhere
Constantly learning and solving new problems
Create tangible products that people use
Strong job market - demand exceeds supply
Low barrier to entry - can be self-taught
International opportunities - work for global companies

myths: You code alone in a dark room all day
You need to be a math genius
You're done learning after you land the job
It's all building cool features and apps
realities: 60% of your time is reading and debugging existing code, not writing new code
You spend 2-3 hours daily in meetings, code reviews, and discussions
You're essentially a professional Googler - nobody memorizes everything
Most days are spent on maintenance, bug fixes, and small improvements
surprises: How much time you spend understanding business requirements, not just coding
Soft skills (communication, empathy) matter as much as technical skills
You'll switch tech stacks every 2-3 years as industry evolves
Imposter syndrome never fully goes away, even for seniors

realityQuiz.description: Experience real scenarios developers face daily. See if this career matches your style.

questions.explanation: Most experienced developers choose option 2 - balancing urgency with smart recovery processes. Production issues happen to everyone.

options.insight: You show strong pressure tolerance and responsibility, but may risk burnout
options.text: Drop everything, cancel dinner, debug immediately until it's fixed

options.insight: You balance urgency with sustainability - key for long-term success
options.text: Document the issue, create a rollback plan, set up monitoring, fix it Monday

options.insight: You value collaboration and know when to ask for help
options.text: Call senior developers immediately for help and guidance

options.insight: High-pressure situations may be challenging - consider if this is right for you
options.text: Feel overwhelmed and panic about the situation

questions.realityNote: 78% of developers face production issues monthly. The best handle it systematically, not heroically.
questions.scenario: It's 6 PM on Friday. Your code broke production and 1,000 users can't access the app. Your team is waiting for you at dinner. What do you do?

questions.explanation: Options 2, 3, and 4 are all valid strategies. The key is knowing when to use each one.

options.insight: Persistence is valuable but can become inefficient without fresh perspectives
options.text: Keep pushing - I'll figure it out eventually

options.insight: You understand the value of mental space in problem-solving
options.text: Take a break, clear your head, come back fresh

options.insight: You leverage collaboration effectively - a key developer skill
options.text: Ask a colleague to pair program and get a second perspective

options.insight: You know how to use available resources efficiently
options.text: Search Stack Overflow and developer forums for similar issues

questions.realityNote: Developers spend 30-40% of their time debugging. Learning to debug efficiently is crucial.
questions.scenario: You've been debugging the same issue for 3 hours with no progress. What's your next move?

questions.explanation: Software changes constantly. Developers learn new technologies multiple times per year.

options.insight: You thrive on continuous learning - perfect for software development
options.text: Excited! Love learning new tech

options.insight: Technology changes constantly - this may cause ongoing stress
options.text: Stressed. Prefer sticking to what I know

options.insight: Smart approach - leveraging team knowledge accelerates learning
options.text: Ask to pair with someone experienced in this tech

options.insight: Self-directed learning is a core developer skill
options.text: Dive into documentation and tutorials immediately

questions.realityNote: Average developer learns 3-5 new frameworks/tools annually. Continuous learning is the job.
questions.scenario: Your manager assigns you a project using a technology you've never used. Deadline is 2 weeks. How do you react?

questions.explanation: Good developers balance assigned work with proactive improvement. Options 1 and 2 show initiative.

options.insight: You show initiative and creativity - valuable traits for senior roles
options.text: Build a quick prototype in my free time to demonstrate the value

options.insight: You balance ideas with team input - collaborative innovation
options.text: Bring it up in the next team meeting for discussion

options.insight: You respect hierarchy and proper channels
options.text: Email my manager privately with the suggestion

options.insight: While focused, you may miss opportunities to add extra value
options.text: Focus on my assigned work - don't want to overstep

questions.realityNote: Many successful products started as developer side projects. Innovation is encouraged.
questions.scenario: You have a brilliant idea for improving the product, but it's not in your assigned tasks. What do you do?

questions.explanation: Code reviews are learning opportunities. Options 1-3 show growth mindset.

options.insight: You value code quality highly, though this may affect work-life balance
options.text: Refactor it now - I want the code to be excellent

options.insight: You balance quality with sustainable work pace
options.text: Schedule refactoring for Monday - it's not urgent

options.insight: You value learning and clear communication
options.text: Ask the reviewer to show me what they mean before changing anything

options.insight: You may struggle with code quality expectations in professional settings
options.text: It works, so I'll leave it - 'if it ain't broke, don't fix it'

questions.realityNote: Code review is standard practice. Expect feedback on 80%+ of your code. It's how teams improve.
questions.scenario: Code review feedback says your code works but could be cleaner. It's Friday afternoon. What do you do?

high.message: Your responses align well with successful software developers. You show good balance between technical skills and collaboration, handle pressure constructively, and understand the importance of continuous learning.
high.title: Strong Developer Potential

low.message: Your responses suggest software development may not be the best fit. This doesn't mean you can't code - many roles use programming differently. Consider data analysis, technical writing, or IT support.
low.title: Consider Other Paths

medium.message: You have some aptitudes for software development but may find certain aspects challenging. Consider which scenarios felt uncomfortable and whether you'd enjoy facing them regularly.
medium.title: Development Career Possible

realityQuiz.title: A Day as a Software Developer

remoteWork.notes: Most software roles in Rwanda offer hybrid or full remote. International remote jobs pay $60-150K but very competitive.

resources.description: Free, comprehensive, self-paced curriculum from zero to job-ready. Best structured free resource.
resources.name: FreeCodeCamp

resources.description: Free full-stack curriculum. More project-based than FCC. Excellent for self-learners.
resources.name: The Odin Project

resources.description: Free, rigorous intro to CS. Challenging but builds strong fundamentals.
resources.name: CS50 (Harvard)

resources.description: Practice coding interviews. Essential for job prep, frustrating but necessary.
resources.name: LeetCode

resources.description: Real design challenges to build portfolio. Makes your projects look professional.
resources.name: Frontend Mentor

resources.description: Local Slack/Discord group. Job postings, mentorship, meetups. Join ASAP.
resources.name: Rwanda Developers Community

resources.description: Follow #100DaysOfCode, engage with devs, share your journey. Leads to opportunities.
resources.name: Twitter Tech Community

shortDescription: Build applications and solve problems with code to create digital solutions.

successStories.advice: Don't wait to feel 'ready' - start freelancing small projects after 3 months of learning. Real projects teach more than tutorials.
successStories.biggestHelp: Twitter tech community introduced me to first freelance client
successStories.hardestPart: Building confidence without formal CS degree. Applying to 100+ jobs.
successStories.name: Grace Uwase
successStories.switchTrigger: Needed remote work flexibility for family, saw tech salaries
successStories.timeline: 18 months (6 months learning + 1 year freelancing + landed full-time)

successStories.advice: Apply even if you don't meet 100% of requirements. Most job descriptions are wish lists. Your portfolio matters more than perfect qualifications.
successStories.biggestHelp: Bootcamp's career coach helped improve resume and interview skills
successStories.hardestPart: Rejection after rejection. Took 9 months and 200 applications to get first offer.
successStories.name: Claude Mugisha
successStories.switchTrigger: Couldn't find business job, friend suggested coding bootcamp

successStories.advice: Your previous career isn't wasted - use industry knowledge as competitive advantage. Build projects solving problems from your old field.
successStories.biggestHelp: Banking domain knowledge got me mid-level role at fintech startup
successStories.hardestPart: Learning to code while working full-time. Exhausting but necessary to pay bills.
successStories.name: Eric Nkusi
successStories.switchTrigger: Saw fintech potential in Rwanda, wanted to build solutions

title: Software Developer

greenFlags: Clear onboarding process with buddy system
Pair programming and code review culture
redFlags: 'We're a family' culture (often means unpaid overtime)
No junior developers on team (no mentorship)
High turnover rate (check LinkedIn for ex-employees)
Unpaid 'test projects' taking more than 4 hours
Unclear product roadmap or business model

goodDay.activity: Deep focus coding - implementing new feature you designed
Code review - giving feedback on teammate's work
Pairing session with junior dev, helping them debug
Writing tests for your new feature

hardDay.activity: Production is down! Emergency Slack messages
Finally found the bug - it was a typo ≡ƒÿà
Skip lunch, still fixing and testing
Post-mortem meeting about what went wrong
Back to planned work, but mentally drained
